unit_status.destruction_context: The 2nd Libyan Division was completely destroyed during Operation Compass on December 11, 1940, before the 1941-Q1 period began. The division was overrun at Tummar on December 9-10, 1940, with 26 officers and 1,327 men killed, 32 officers and 804 men wounded, and all survivors taken prisoner. This unit did not exist during 1941-Q1.

supply_logistics.fuel_details: Italian Tenth Army trucks consuming 60% of fuel just to reach forward units from Libyan bases (Benghazi, Tobruk, Tripoli). Supply lines stretched hundreds of miles across destroyed coastal road.
supply_logistics.ammunition_details: Limited shipping capacity from Italy to Libya meant ammunition competed with fuel, water, food and spare parts for transport. Division destroyed before ammunition became critical factor.
supply_logistics.water_details: Water shortage was principal reason Tenth Army halted at Sidi Barrani in September 1940. Desert environment required extensive water supply, but transport infrastructure inadequate.
supply_logistics.operational_radius_details: Division positioned in static defensive camp at Tummar, limited mobility. L3 tankettes had 125km range but fuel shortages limited actual operational radius.
supply_logistics.supply_chain_details: British scorched earth policy destroyed coastal road. Supplies shipped from Italy to Benghazi/Tobruk/Tripoli, then trucked hundreds of miles. Spare parts, fuel, water, ammunition, and food all competing for limited transport capacity. Division destroyed December 9-11, 1940 before supply situation could improve.

weather_environment.terrain_details: Open desert terrain near Egyptian coast at Tummar. Fortified camp positions. British exploited 20-mile wide Enba gap between Italian defensive positions. Minimal natural cover.
weather_environment.temperature_range: December: 10-20°C daytime, near freezing at night
weather_environment.temperature_details: Winter conditions in North African coastal desert. Battle of Sidi Barrani (Dec 9-10, 1940) fought in cold temperatures with bitter winds.
weather_environment.seasonal_impacts_details: December 10, 1940: Appalling weather with bitter winds whipping thick dust clouds, visibility reduced to 50 yards at times. Huge sandstorm during the day slowed British advance but did not prevent complete Italian defeat. Severe sandstorm affected operations at Sidi Barrani and Tummar.
weather_environment.environmental_challenges: Desert navigation, sandstorms reducing visibility, water scarcity, extreme temperature variations day/night, dust affecting mechanical equipment, limited natural defensive positions requiring fortified camps

combat_history.operational_summary: The 2nd Libyan Division was formed March 1, 1940 as a colonial formation with Italian officers and Libyan troops. Participated in the Italian invasion of Egypt in September 1940, advancing to Sidi Barrani where it halted due to critical supply shortages (especially water). Established static defensive positions at Tummar camps. When British Operation Compass launched December 9, 1940, the division's IX Tank Battalion was annihilated in the afternoon, followed by complete division destruction over next 48 hours. Division declared lost December 11, 1940. Total service life: 9 months, 10 days.
